com.stormpath.sdk.authc
Class UsernamePasswordRequest

java.lang.Object
  com.stormpath.sdk.authc.UsernamePasswordRequest
All Implemented Interfaces:
AuthenticationRequest<String,char[]>
public class UsernamePasswordRequest
extends Object
implements AuthenticationRequest<String,char[]>

A UsernamePasswordRequest is an AuthenticationRequest that represents a username (or email) + password pair. It optionally supports targeting an specific account store as well for customized authentication behavior.

Since:
0.2

UsernamePasswordRequest

public UsernamePasswordRequest(String usernameOrEmail,
                               String password,
                               AccountStore accountStore)
Constructs a new UsernamePasswordRequest with the specified username (or email) and password, ensuring the authentication request will be directly targeted at the application's specified AccountStore (thereby bypassing the application's default account store authentication flow). The AccountStore must be assigned to the application sending the request.

Usage

Most applications will not need to specify an AccountStore during an authentication attempt, but specifying one can be useful in some cases, such as when an Application has many (dozens or hundreds) of assigned account stores: in this case specifying an account store will result in a direct (targeted) authentication which would be faster because Stormpath does not need to iteratively try each assigned account store as documented.

Parameters:
usernameOrEmail - the account's username or email address
password - the account's raw password
accountStore - an application's specific AccountStore that should process the authentication request, thereby bypassing the application's default account store authentication flow.
Since:
1.0.alpha

Constructs a new UsernamePasswordRequest with the specified username (or email) and password, ensuring the authentication request will be directly targeted at the application's specified AccountStore (thereby bypassing the application's default account store authentication flow). UsernamePasswordRequest

public UsernamePasswordRequest(String usernameOrEmail,
                               String password,
                               String host,
                               AccountStore accountStore)
Constructs a new UsernamePasswordRequest with the specified usernameOrEmail and password for an end-user accessing the application from the specified host, also ensuring the authentication request will be directly targeted at the application's specified AccountStore (thereby bypassing the application's default account store authentication flow). The AccountStore must be assigned to the application sending the request.

Usage

Most applications will not need to specify an AccountStore during an authentication attempt, but specifying one can be useful in some cases, such as when an Application has many (dozens or hundreds) of assigned account stores: in this case specifying an account store will result in a direct (targeted) authentication which would be faster because Stormpath does not need to iteratively try each assigned account store as documented.

Parameters:
usernameOrEmail - the account's username or email address
password - the account's raw password
host - the host from where the end-user is accessing your application
accountStore - an application's specific AccountStore that should process the authentication request, thereby bypassing the application's default account store authentication flow.

1.0.alpha

getAccountStore

public AccountStore getAccountStore()
Returns a specific AccountStore that should process this authentication request, or null if the application's default account store authentication flow should execute. If non-null, the account store must be assigned to the application sending the request.

This is an optional property, so the default is null, reflecting an application's default authentication flow.

Usage

Most applications will not need to specify an AccountStore during an authentication attempt, but specifying one can be useful in some cases, such as when an Application has many (dozens or hundreds) of assigned account stores: in this case specifying an account store will result in a direct (targeted) authentication which would be faster because Stormpath does not need to iteratively try each assigned account store as documented.

Specified by:
getAccountStore in interface AuthenticationRequest<String,char[]>
Returns:
a specific AccountStore that should process this authentication request, or null if the application's default account store authentication flow should execute. If non-null, the account store must be assigned to the application sending the request.
Since:
1.0.alpha

setAccountStore

public void setAccountStore(AccountStore accountStore)
Sets a specific AccountStore that should process this authentication request, or null if the application's default account store authentication flow should execute. If non-null, the account store must be assigned to the application sending the request.

This is an optional property, so the default is null, reflecting an application's default authentication flow.

Usage

Most applications will not need to specify an AccountStore during an authentication attempt, but specifying one can be useful in some cases, such as when an Application has many (dozens or hundreds) of assigned account stores: in this case specifying an account store will result in a direct (targeted) authentication which would be faster because Stormpath does not need to iteratively try each assigned account store as documented.

Parameters:
accountStore - a specific AccountStore that should process this authentication request, or null if the application's default account store authentication flow should execute. If non-null, the account store must be assigned to the application sending the request.
Since:
1.0.alpha

clear

public void clear()
Clears out (nulls) the username, password, and host. The password bytes are explicitly set to 0x00 to eliminate the possibility of memory access at a later time.

Specified by:
clear in interface AuthenticationRequest<String,char[]>
